nodes.text: District A would be a Hispanic opportunity district, and both districts would provide a broader consideration of the City’s needs and an opportunity for us to benefit from the experience of otherwise term-limited council members. /21
For more information, the Austin Common has reports on each of the propositions /22 https://t.co/6vZ8AE3way
I’d still like to see us discuss adding two superdistricts to Council, a District A comprising Districts 1-5 and a District B made up of Districts 6-10. /20
We need to have a frank, open discussion about what has been working and what hasn’t. /19

The common theme running through these propositions is that there is much that hasn’t been working about Austin’s government. And, this doesn’t even include past issues like the City Attorney and land development code. /18
In the last election, Hispanic challengers forced a runoff in District 1. If we don’t vote for Prop G, we may not have an African-American on Council in 2027. /17

If we don’t add a Council district, when we rebalance and adjust the boundaries of the Council districts later this year in response to the census results, it will likely be difficult to draw an African-American district. /16
Prop G – Yes. We need to vote to increase the size of the Council, regardless of if we vote for a strong mayor. /15
How to restructure our government for greater accountability is definitely something we need to discuss. /14
Some have pointed out the need for professional management of our city. Even without a City Manager, Austin would still have six deputy and assistant city managers and numerous department heads. /12

I’m voting for this proposal mainly as a vote to keep the conversation alive. For this and other propositions, we would have greatly benefited if Council had organized a charter revision commission to discuss the proposals. /13
Prop F – Yes. I’m not wild about this proposal – particularly the veto provision – but I’m more concerned about the dysfunction under our current Council-Manager government. /11
Voting in favor of ranked choice voting sends a message that we want it as an option. /10

Prop E – Yes. Ranked choice voting is great way to show people that their votes matter. And, it is far better to decide elections through ranked-choice voting than through expensive, low-turnout runoffs. So what if it’s not currently allowed under State law? /9

And, having the mayoral election in a presidential election year will likely be more expensive. We should work on real barriers to voting, and people need to see that it is important to turn out in election years when we’re voting for Governor and other public offices./8
Moving our local elections to November has increased turnout, even with the falloff from those who only vote the top of the ballot. But, it has also made our local elections more partisan. /7
Prop D – No. I am all in favor of getting more people to vote in our mayoral elections. I’m not in favor of telling people that it is okay to show up only once every four years to vote. /6

Prop C – Yes. Placing the Office of Police Oversight directly under the Council will be a welcome improvement. This is also a good illustration of the problems that we’ve been having under our current Council-Manager government. /5
If you want to send a message to city hall, there are better opportunities further down the ballot. /4

Prop B – No. We need to address the homeless camps. But, this isn’t it. This will only drive the camps back into the woods. Out of sight, out of mind. There are multiple efforts underway to provide housing and address homelessness. /3

Prop A – No. I am sympathetic to the goal of breaking the impasse in the firefighter contract negotiations. But, I am highly suspicious of binding arbitration where the decision of an arbiter is not subject to judicial review. /2
Voting for the May 1st elections begins Monday, 4/19. In Austin, we’ve got a number of ballot propositions to consider. Here are my thoughts and recommendations. /1
